docs.lead_paragraph: See the title and brace for heartbreak. See the title and brace for transformational beauty. The speaker, too, is trying to see the title, the name, the answer to the question the daughter asks. You are witness to an intimate scene between parents and their child. Or you are there with the child climbing into your lap. The silence is as tender as the chewed petals of a flower, a wreath. There are no words for the haunting final sentence. Selected by Terrance Hayes

docs.lead_paragraph: Reading this wildly spirited poem leaves a wondrous “wow” in the mouth. Are those check marks or dashes laddering the left side? It’s a column of vibrating sounds. Pink cypripedium, herbarium, Aeolian, buttercup. The whipping polysyllabics are anchored to the poem’s only question: “How’s that for lonely?” The sound holds the weight of a headstone, a granite edge. The poem intensifies a familiar depiction of Emily Dickinson. It makes a portrait with Dickinson both demystified and mystified. Selected by Terrance Hayes

headline.main: Poem: Self-Portrait With Emily Dickinson (Rebirth of Mourning)
headline.print_headline: Self-Portrait With Emily Dickinson (Rebirth of Mourning)

docs.abstract: The Nine Inch Nails frontman on Facebook, Vietnam and Midwest “weirdo culture.”
docs.snippet: The Nine Inch Nails frontman on Facebook, Vietnam and Midwest “weirdo culture.”
docs.lead_paragraph: “Bad Witch,” your ninth studio album with Nine Inch Nails, is the final record of a politically-minded trilogy you began in 2016. Do you feel that musicians have a responsibility to address politics? I was doing press with somebody in the mid-90s, and they made an argument that stayed with me: that I have influence, and that it’s my job to call out whatever needs to be called out, because there are people who feel the same way but need someone to articulate it. And I think about that today, because it seemed like it was a lot easier to just keep your mouth shut and let it go back then. You don’t hear a lot from the Taylor Swifts of the world, and top-tier, needle-moving cultural youth, because they are concerned about their brand, their demographic and their success and career and whatnot.

headline.main: Trent Reznor Thinks Artists Should Speak Out
headline.print_headline: Trent Reznor Thinks Artists Should Speak Out

docs.abstract: Crack a coconut open for the Puerto Rican dessert tembleque.
docs.snippet: Crack a coconut open for the Puerto Rican dessert tembleque.
docs.lead_paragraph: You can split a hairy, brown coconut in two with a machete, if you’ve got one lying around. The force of a well-aimed throw against concrete will sometimes do the trick. At close range, you can clobber away at it using the blunt side of a cleaver and plenty of muscle, and it will, eventually, fracture all the way around the middle so that you can get to the sweet-smelling water inside and the firm, fatty meat. On a recent Friday morning in her kitchen in Brooklyn, Von Diaz was going to use an electric drill to break in, but when she realized its battery was dead, she improvised. She balanced a coconut in the groove of her kitchen sink and chiseled the top with a screwdriver and a hammer. This worked, too. After puncturing it in its three dark eyes and saving the cloudy water that dribbled out, Diaz bashed the shell wide open.

headline.main: A Delicately Sweet and Floral Coconut Pudding for the Summer

docs.abstract: It’s the one category broad enough to make tiny mistakes sound like grave errors, and terrible violations sound like simple misunderstandings.
docs.snippet: It’s the one category broad enough to make tiny mistakes sound like grave errors, and terrible violations sound like simple misunderstandings.
docs.lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, “inappropriate” described things that were “not done,” like wearing white after Labor Day or congratulating the bride. It applied to minor transgressions against codes of social behavior, formules de politesse. These days, though, it’s an alarm. To hear it used in connection with your name is no doubt to imagine the heart-stopping worst: revelations of shameful behavior, firings and resignations, public loathing and perp walks.

headline.main: ‘Inappropriate’ Behavior Could Mean a Faux Pas — Or a Crime

byline.original: By The New York Times Magazine

docs.lead_paragraph: How fitting that in the month of American independence we come to celebrate the outgoing editor for this space. Terrance Hayes has, with more than a bit of shade, created his own brand of hip-hop sonnet. Just as the United States are multifarious and contradictory and complicated, he went on until he had accumulated an entire collection of sonnets, all bar none with the same title. Truly, a tour de force! “The song must be cultural, confessional, clear” — a pithy ars poetica for our volatile age. Hayes’s word plays, from homonyms to the transmogrification of Sturm und Drang into “storm and drum,” are less linguistic jokes than wry descriptions of an Anglo-America that has taken the historical discourse of Western civilization to its own brash level. And in case you were hoping to be let off easy, beware: The last line may stick in your throat. Selected by Rita Dove

headline.main: Poem: American Sonnet for My Past and Future Assassin
